content.name: 12th Aylesbury Brownies
content.description: Brownies are a group of girls aged 7 to 10 years who meet weekly in term time for fun activities, crafts, songs, badge work, games, learning new skills and making new friends.

survey_answers.question: What outcomes does your setting, service or activity aim to achieve for children and young people with SEND and their families?
What recent SEND-specific training has been completed by your staff and/or volunteers?
How do you involve parents and how can I get involved?
How will you share information with me about my child’s progress? What is additional for children with SEND?
How accessible is the environment (indoors and outdoors)?
How can children and young people with SEND and their families start to use your service or activity?
What future plans do you have for developing your SEND provision?

content.name: 13 plus days | Tuesdays and Thursdays
content.description:
These are for 13 year olds and upwards who have disabilities.
All outside areas open, access to toilets and cafe from our outside hatch plus different planned activities and sensory room. 
Please check our website for dates and activities.

organisation.name: Thomley
organisation.description:
We welcome disabled people of all ages from babies to adults, and their families, carers or friends. We support people at any stage of their diagnostic journey, whatever their additional needs.
We offer regular days for disabled visitors and their families. We also offer focus days for preschool children, adults, schools, respite groups and the wider community when any family can join us to enjoy our facilities.
Our site is spacious and secure, with an excellent range of fully-accessible facilities. Each day our friendly and experienced staff run fun and educational activities which cater for all ages and abilities.
We are open 10am to 3:30pm, Tuesday to Saturday. In the school holidays we open on Mondays too.
We also run evening youth clubs for disabled teenagers and take bookings for birthday parties and disability events. Take a look at our website to see when would be best to visit our website.
Our centre is just outside the village of Worminghall between Oxford and Aylesbury.

content.name: 1st Chesham Scout Group
content.description:
One of three Scout Groups in Chesham offering the enjoyment and structure of Scouting for boys and girl.
Beavers
Beaver Scouts like:

Being creative: making things and singing
Playing games
Going on visits and investigating nature
Learning about themselves
Getting to know other people
Discovering the worlds of science, nature and technology
Exploring the natural and human-made world
Caring: responding to the needs of others, the local and international community

 
Cubs
Boys and girls:

Go camping
Play games
Explore the outdoors
Try adventurous activities: such as climbing, sailing and archery
Meet people from their local community
Experience the culture of other countries
Keep themselves and others safe

 
Scouts
In the Troop Scouts:

Develop leadership skills
Learn emergency aid
Spend nights away
Help others in the community
Cook, both at home and at camp
Adventurous and sporting activities: anything from abseiling to zorbing
Learn survival skills

content.name: 1st Kingshill Scout Group
content.description:
1st Kingshill Scout Group has approximately 70 boys and girls in our Beaver, Cub and Scout sections, mostly from the villages and schools of Great and Little Kingshill, between Great Missenden and High Wycombe.
We offer a great variety of activities for our children, encouraging widespread contact and involvement between the sections and also with the member’s whole family.

content.name: 2HelpUXL Mentoring and Support
content.description:
What do we offer
2HelpUXL is a community-led mentoring and support organisation which prides itself to ‘Empower, Encourage, Enthuse’ children and young people within the local community through a bespoke engagement model. The purpose of the mentoring initiative is to provide “Supportive, assistance, advocacy or guidance given by one person to another in order to achieve an objective or several objectives over a period of time”.
This innovative sustainable approach involves:


Mentoring and Wellbeing support


Transformation through Nutrition


Motivational Workshops


Storytelling


Community Outreach Programs


We believe in the well-being of Children and Young People and want to create a platform that facilitates in raising; potential, confidence, social interaction, behaviour and academic performance. 
Why was 2HelpUXL created?
It was created with students, teachers, and parents in mind to:

To empower the child, young person or family unit to achieve their full potential
To create an environment that educates, enthuses and innovates the minds of each child and young person.
Raising confidence and self-esteem, to develop new and existing skills, overcoming any weaknesses and obstacles
Tackling barriers to learning. To raise the attainment and aspirations of students who have the potential to progress to Higher Education.

How

Mentoring will take the form of group settings and 1:1 sessions to suit individuals' preferred needs.

The emotional well-being of children and young people is extremely important and sometimes all they need is someone they can connect with and help support them in various aspects of their lives. We offer 1:1 mentoring to individuals as a form of early intervention and a source of helping to raise potential, social interaction, behaviour and attention along with academic performance and standards.
Project Holiday
The aim is to empower, encourage and enthuse individuals who are with the Foster Care and Looked After Children services. The objective of the project is to run a series of sessions in High Wycombe and Aylesbury area over a maximum of a 6-12 week period as either a school holiday or a weekend programme. The programme will not only benefit the child or young person but the carers and families in which they live.
The sessions will look to focus on topics such as:

Identity – Who Am I?
Pursuing your goals and dreams
History and culture
Confidence and self-esteem
Celebration

2HelpUXL in Schools and Project STORIE STORIE
We would like to introduce to you an empowering and creative movement that we believe will be of great interest to you. 2HelpUXL caters for all and believes it is an extra source of encouragement and motivation.
We are excited to announce that we have teamed up with the award-winning public speaker Alim Kamara to bring you project STORIE STORIE ‘Motivation through Storytelling’. Alim brings positivity to your classroom by sparking imagination and raising aspirations. He has delivered storytelling and inspirational talks and performances to schools and colleges all over the world from Dubai and Holland to The United States of America and Gambia.
This is the perfect seminar to get young people motivated. It does exactly what it means; it empowers, encourages and enthuses children and young people to help them excel to their full potential and become a successful individual. This interactive seminar inspires young people of all ages and abilities to excel in their strengths and work harder in areas they find challenging, like exams and studying.
We look at the relationship between determination, goal setting, and success. Through this seminar young people are creatively taught ‘the blueprint of success’ along with simple techniques to stay focused in order to achieve great results and reach career ambitions.
Find out more
Visit our website or check out our YouTube trailer.

content.name: 627 Transfer
content.description:
627 Transfer provides transfer support for Year 6s and Year 7s in Buckinghamshire to help them move smoothly to and succeed at secondary school.
We:

prepare children for the differences at secondary school
address specific concerns and anxieties
build confidence and raise self-esteem
teach a range of social and organisational skills important for success at secondary school and life in general

We offer:

individual/small group sessions and large group workshops to primary and secondary schools
customised support to parents/carers
online sessions available

Visit our website for:

advice on how to support children with their move to secondary school
information about the services 627 Transfer provides
tips, information and games to aid transfer in the For Children area

content.name: ABA Horizons
content.description:
ABA (Applied Behavioural Analysis) Horizons believes every child can learn. Especially when given the right tools and support. Despite if they learn differently from you and me. We strive to help young people on the spectrum to maximise their potential.
Based on the principles of Applied Behaviour Analysis, we provide high quality, individualised services. We increase effective learning by reducing barriers that prevent learning. We teach functionally equivalent skills to replace behaviours that may challenge.
Telehealth ABA Programmes will allow for families to have access to ABA programmes through the use of technology.  It is cost-effective for families with a child who cannot meet in traditional standards of face-to-face consultations and examinations. It can improve the child's health through real-time communication between the therapist and the child in a remote environment.  ABA Horizons makes use of electronic communication using audio and video equipment to engage with the child.  This allows for flexibility and for the family and child to receive high-quality services.
Direct Services - Our direct ABA services consist of 1:1 therapy provided to your child for a specified number of hours per week in the home or community setting. The exact number of hours will be based on assessment results and what we think will work best for you. Direct services will be implemented by an RBT® or RBT® in training.  We understand that ABA services can be expensive and time-consuming, therefore we want our services to be accessible and work for your budget. If you are interested in direct ABA services, there are three possible RBT® options available to you:  ABA Horizons provides a tutor with RBT® certification. You provide a tutor that already has RBT® certification or that we can train to RBT® standard. You work directly with your child and ABA Horizons will train you to RBT® standard.
In addition to 1:1 therapy, it is recommended that parents/caregivers receive parent training to run alongside therapy. The purpose of parent training is to ensure that the skills your child learns during therapy generalise to other people and settings. Parent training will help you to better understand your child’s learning and behaviour.

locations.name: 43 Chapman Place, Mile End, Colchester, CO4 5ZJ

content.name: Abbey View Primary Academy
content.description:
Abbey View Primary Academy will be committed to delivering inspirational learning opportunities that are fun, purposeful and challenging. We want our children not just to achieve, but to exceed expectations and attain the very best results they can academically, creatively and personally. Our pupils will take ownership of their learning, becoming highly aspirational and resilient learners who are able to make positive contributions to life in modern Britain.
Our pupils will be at the heart of every decision we make and we will offer a safe, nurturing and creative learning environment, which will enable us to foster a passion for learning and curiosity in a happy and supported way.

content.description: Playgroup style Pre-School located in the Well End side of Bourne End. An emphasis on learning through play, supporting the children to develop the skills needed to transition into school with confidence. Through our well qualified and highly experienced practitioners.

content.name: Abbotts View Alpacas Private Group Visits
content.description:
We are a small, private, family run farm in Aston Abbotts, Buckinghamshire, where we breed alpacas and rare breed sheep and pigs. We welcome visits from a wide range of groups and, as our farm is private we tailor each visit to the needs of the group. We can cater for groups from minimum 15 up to 30 and can include private farm tours, walking the alpacas, educational activities, craft activities and home made cakes and refreshments. Each is dependent on what you would like to include so you can do as little or as much as you require.
Bookings are taken from March until October on week days. We don't recommend alpaca walks for children under the age of 10 or for groups larger than 30 but can offer private farm tours.

content.name: ABC Fantastic Home Learning
content.description:
At ABC Fantastic Home Learning, your child can benefit from bespoke face-to-face online tuition via Zoom, delivered by a qualified, experienced primary school teacher with a DBS certificate. Support for English and Maths, tuition for those shielding, preparing for Grammar school entry exams, regular term-time or holiday lessons available, as well as ad hoc lessons and intensive courses are just some of the services we offer.
Find out more including our prices by visiting our website or by emailing us.

content.name: ABLEize | Disability and Special Needs Resources
content.description:
ABLEize is a disability run website dedicated to providing the UK’s largest collection of disability and special needs online resources in an ever-growing directory putting disabled people, their family and carers in touch with information, advice, support, groups and clubs, disability sports, the arts and much more within 420 plus dedicated categories. Established in 2006 ABLEize was created and is run by disabled people offering both national and local resources under one safe roof.
ABLEize is maintained and added to regularly by its group of disabled researchers to ensure the information is kept up to date. Typical resources include disabled children’s resources, the arts for all disabilities and special needs, sports and support, access and travel assistance through to benefits, care services, employment and disabled and special needs education to name just a few. You will also find the UK’s largest collection of disability-related clubs and groups all listed in individual regional categories. 
Buckinghamshire Disability Resources can be found by following the highlighted link and includes many sports and support groups specific to the range of Buckinghamshire locations. In light to the recent COVID-19, we have created a dedicated list of Buckinghamshire Mental Health Support services and contacts including online and telephone support services offered by official organisations. Please click the highlighted
Other disability and special needs related subjects can be searched from the front page of ABLEize but for the convenience of the viewer, we have included a shortcut to the most viewed sections of ABLEize. 


Children's Disability Resources


Disabled Children's Holidays


Live-in Carers


Adaptive and Special Needs Clothing


Disability Arts


Respite Care


Disabled Accessible Holidays


Home Automation for the Disabled


Special Needs Footwear


Special Needs Education


Arthritis Care Treatment


Disabled Schools and Colleges


Multi-Sensory Play Therapy


Disability Sports


Accessible Housing


ABLEize would like to thank Buckinghamshire Council for helping to get the information to those with a special need or disability, their carers and family.

content.name: ABRSM Piano, Keyboard and Organ Lessons (Buckinghamshire)
content.description:
Have you ever wanted to learn to play the keyboard, piano or organ? Would you like lessons in the comfort of your own home? Then why don t you call Leisure Play.
All ages are welcome, learn fast and easily with a friendly professional tutor. ABRSM Piano Grades full recommendations can be seen, all music books are FREE and lessons are 1 hour from just £15, £20  7 days a week, covering the Buckinghamshire area.  
Please call ANDY or leave a message when calling hope to hear from you soon.

content.name: Access to Work Programme | Assistance for those with a Disability
content.description:
If you’re disabled or have a physical or mental health condition that makes it hard for you to do your job, you can:

talk to your employer about changes they must make in your workplace
get extra help from Access to Work, including mental health support

Apply
Check you’re eligible before you apply.
You can apply for Access to Work online or by phone.
You’ll need to provide:

your workplace address and postcode
the name of a workplace contact who can authorise your Access to Work payments
your workplace contact’s email address or work phone number
your unique tax reference number (if you’re self-employed)

You’ll also need to explain:

how your condition affects you at work or getting to work
what help you’re already getting
what else could help you

It will help your application if you’ve spoken to your employer about reasonable adjustments before you apply for Access to Work.
Talk to your employer about changes they must make in your workplace
Your employer must make certain changes (known as ‘reasonable adjustments’) to make sure you’re not substantially disadvantaged when doing your job. These could include changing your working hours or providing equipment to help you do your job.
You should talk to your employer about reasonable adjustments before you apply for Access to Work.
Get help from Access to Work
If the help you need at work is not covered by your employer making reasonable adjustments, you may be able to get help from Access to Work.
You need to have a paid job, or be about to start or return to one.
You’ll be offered support based on your needs, which may include a grant to help cover the costs of practical support in the workplace.
An Access to Work grant can pay for:

special equipment, adaptations or support worker services to help you do things like answer the phone or go to meetings
help getting to and from work

You might not get a grant if you already get certain benefits.
The money does not have to be paid back and will not affect your other benefits.
There’s a different system in Northern Ireland.
Get mental health support
You can apply for Access to Work to get mental health support, or contact a Mental Health Support Service provider directly

content.name: Aces Wheelchair Basketball
content.description:
Aces Wheelchair Basketball Club has teams that play in both the junior and senior BWB national leagues.
The club trains on Friday evenings at Stoke Mandeville Stadium. During the basketball season (usually from the end of September until the end of May) teams will have matches at home or away over the weekends.
Please contact us for more information.

content.name: Acre Wood Nursery School
content.description:
Inside the impressive knapped building that is Acre Wood Nursery School you'll find a bustling atmosphere with fun and laughter of children enjoying their day.
At Acre Wood we understand that your child is unique with their own personality and special gifts.
Children are encouraged to grow and develop at their own pace in fun and exciting surroundings.
Caring for, educating and entertaining children aged six weeks to five years, five days a week. Our extensive facilities, both indoors and out have everything your growing child needs.

content.name: Action for Children (Aylesbury Club, Buckingham Road)
content.description:
Due to Coronavirus (COVID-19) this Short Breaks Service is currently closed. Find out more on the Short Breaks Page.
Coronavirus (Covid-19) – Short Breaks Service Closure We have recently had to make the difficult decision to close our short breaks services provided by Action for Children due to the coronavirus outbreak. We want to keep families and our care and health workers safe. This means that we must follow government guidance on staying at home and social distancing. Letters have been sent out to all families who are affected by this decision. We are committed to reopening short breaks services as soon as it is safe to do so and we will continue to contact families directly with any updates. Updates will also be posted on this page.
In the meantime it is important that you keep yourself and others safe by following government guidance on staying at home and social distancing. The Council has set up a community support hub with lots of advice and information www.buckinghamshire.gov.uk/coronavirus
We know that this a very worrying time for many families and we are doing all we can to offer continued support to parents, carers and children.
If you are worried and need help you can contact us as follows:

If your child/ren have a social worker please call 01296 383 762
If your family has a family support worker from the Early Help Service please call 01296 383293
If your child/ren do not have a social worker or a family support worker please call First Response Team: Telephone: 01296 383 962 (Monday to Friday, 9am to 5pm) If you need an urgent response outside of these hours, contact the Emergency Duty Team on 0800 999 7677



We provide short breaks for children with disabilities and/or additional learning needs, giving parents and carers a rest from their caring responsibilities and chance for children and young people to gain independence, socialise with peers and have fun! Our sessions include a mix of venue based sessions and activities out and about in the local community at weekends and during school holidays. We also run youth clubs for teens in High Wycombe and Aylesbury. Staff are on hand to meet the needs of each individual child, supporting them to participate fully in the activity they are attending.
How to book: Please register your child with Bucks Activity Project by emailing us at Bucks.activity@actionforchildren.org.uk or telephone the office on 01296 438230.
